author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Top N.Y.P.D. Chief Injured While Making Arrest at a Protest
description: Terence A. Monahan, New York’s highest-ranking uniformed chief, was one of several officers who were attacked on the Brooklyn Bridge, officials said.
content: New York City’s top uniformed police officer, two lieutenants and a sergeant were injured on Wednesday in two separate incidents on the Brooklyn Bridge, including one that involved an attack with some kind of stick or pole as protesters marched nearby, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: To Make Orchestras More Diverse, End Blind Auditions
description: If ensembles are to reflect the communities they serve, the audition process should take into account race, gender and other factors.
content: During the tumultuous summer of 1969, two Black musicians accused the New York Philharmonic of discrimination. Earl Madison, a cellist, and J. Arthur Davis, a bassist, said they had been rejected for positions because of their race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Flannery’ Review: Stories About a Writer
description: Flannery O’Connor created a still-disturbing body of work; but this documentary is surprisingly flat.
content: This biographical documentary of the writer Flannery O’Connor, directed by Mark Bosco and Elizabeth Coffman, is sporadically informative. But it mostly underscores the shortcomings of the varied methods it uses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Unisex jerkins, raw vinegars, classic sportswear — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: NASA Delays James Webb Telescope Launch Date, Again
description: The universe will have to wait a little longer.
content: After years of budget overruns, testing problems and political difficulties, NASA’s next great telescope has been delayed again, the space agency announced Thursday. The James Webb Space Telescope, which was proceeding toward a launch date of March 2021, will now be launched no sooner than Oct. 31, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reopening, Warily: Revisiting Jasmine Lombrage
description: A restaurant owner in Louisiana grappled with the decision to reopen. This is what has happened to her since.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Feiler
title: Feeling Stuck? Five Tips for Managing Life Transitions
description: Whatever the wolf is that disrupts your story, here are ways to emerge as the hero.
content: The Italians have a wonderful expression for how our lives get upended when we least expect it: “lupus in fabula.” It means “the wolf in the fairy tale.” Just when life is going swimmingly, along comes a demon, a dragon, a diagnosis, a downsizing. Just when our fairy tale seems poised to come true, a big, scary thing threatens to destroy everything around it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Galleries Reopen, Two Critics Find Rewards Eclipse the Angst
description: Holland Cotter masks up on the Lower East Side and SoHo; Jillian Steinhauer discovers eco-feminist art taking root in Chelsea.
content: In the New York art world, normal is still a long hike down the pike, but some of the city’s galleries are tiptoeing in that direction with socially distanced reopenings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Airbnb Says Its I.P.O. Plans Are Back on Track
description: After a financial hit from the pandemic, the San Francisco company said business was starting to return from its nose-dive.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb has resumed its efforts to go public, despite significant damage to the home rental business caused by the coronavirus pandemic, Airbnb’s chief executive, Brian Chesky, told employees Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: Keeping Kids Curious About Their Bodies Without Shame
description: It’s natural and entirely harmless for young children to explore. But it’s also important for parents to set boundaries.
content: A mother received an awkward email from her son’s kindergarten teacher last fall. Her 6-year-old and his friends had been caught unzipping their pants and flashing each other during lunch. The behavior was not unusual for his age, the teacher wrote, but it was inappropriate at school. She had spoken with him, and she hoped the parents could address it at home, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz and Kellen Browning
title: FaZe Clan President Departs: ‘It’s Time for Gaming to Clean Up Its Act’
description: Greg Selkoe is leaving the successful esports conglomerate to start a new venture that’s less “frat house” and more diverse.
content: FaZe Clan, an esports lifestyle conglomerate, helped turn gamers into a new class of social media influencers. Now, several top executives behind FaZe Clan are leaving to start a competing organization called XSET.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Wheeler
title: It’s Been 75 Years, and America Still Won’t Admit a Nuclear Disaster
description: Remember when we blew radioactive ash over New Mexico? Now the Trump administration is talking about testing bombs again.
content: When America detonated the world’s first atomic bomb at 0529 hours on July 16, 1945, it was an attack on American soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Shamima Begum, Who Joined ISIS in Syria, Can Return to U.K., Court Says
description: Ms. Begum, now 20, left London in 2015 and was stripped of her British citizenship. Since stranded in a refugee camp, she may be allowed home to appeal the decision.
content: LONDON — Shamima Begum, a woman who traveled to Syria from London as a schoolgirl to join ISIS, should be allowed to return to appeal the government’s decision to strip her of her British citizenship, a court ruled on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Do Cinematographers Have a Signature? Let’s Try a Test
description: The very different “Elephant Man” and “Cape Fear” share similarities that you might put down to the work of one director of photography, Freddie Francis.
content: Last month the film enthusiasts of Twitter took up a new meme: A user would post the line “these two movies have the same cinematographer” and add two images. The joke was that it was hard to believe that, say, Janusz Kaminski, the Oscar-winning cinematographer of “Schindler’s List,” could count among his credits the Vanilla Ice cash-in “Cool as Ice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Online Map Collection Provides a Peek at New York Over the Centuries
description: The Brooklyn Historical Society’s collection of nearly 1,500 digitized maps dates back to the 17th century.
content: When Alexander Hamilton stepped foot in New York City in 1772, the then-village of Brooklyn was more agricultural than artisan, more traditional than trendy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Matisse Thybulle Is the Breakout (Mini-Movie) Star of the N.B.A. Bubble
description: The rookie guard for the Philadelphia 76ers is using his camera skills to give basketball fans a glimpse of the jokes, games and snacks at Walt Disney World in Florida.
content: Not long after the N.B.A. suspended its season in March because of the coronavirus pandemic, Matisse Thybulle began looking for ways to occupy his time. He read books. He worked out. He also discovered TikTok, the video-sharing platform that seemed a natural fit for an avid photographer like himself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Shatters Its Record of New Coronavirus Infections as India’s Caseload Hits a Million
description: The United States reported more than 75,600 new cases on Thursday, a single-day record. India ranks third in the world in both total cases and new ones, and its rate of new infections is on track to overtake Brazil’s.
content: As clashes over face-covering mandates and school reopening plans intensified throughout the United States, the country shattered its single-day record for new cases on Thursday — more than 75,600, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Praachi Raniwala
title: Unfamiliar Territory for Indian Bridal Industry
description: From altering their production schedule to shifting to e-commerce, many Indian fashion brands are adapting in order to stay afloat during the pandemic.
content: When the Indian fashion designer Sabyasachi Mukherjee debuted his fine jewelry at Bergdorf Goodman in January, he had big plans for promoting his collection. But the coronavirus outbreak forced him and the luxury department-store chain to make some big adjustments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: In the Same Towns, Private Schools Are Reopening While Public Schools Are Not
description: Private schools have always had more flexibility, and usually more money, but never has that disparity made a bigger difference than now.
content: In Honolulu, nearly all public schools are planning to allow students to return for just part of the week. But at Punahou, a private school for grades kindergarten through 12, school will open full time for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haig Papazian
title: She Waved a Rainbow Flag at Our Cairo Show. Tragedy Followed.
description: That Sarah Hegazi felt safe enough to honor our music with her bravery is thrilling; that such a simple act forever altered and then ended her life brings me great sorrow.
content: Last month, Sarah Hegazi, a 30-year-old Egyptian L.G.B.T.Q. rights activist, took her own life in Canada. Far away from Cairo, her home, she was profoundly haunted by what had happened to her there over the past two and a half years, having been arrested, tortured and hounded into exile. Her transgression? She raised the rainbow flag — unabashedly and joyously — at a concert in Cairo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: The New Must-Have Museum Souvenir: Face Masks
description: As cultural institutions across Europe reopen, many are selling face coverings featuring their artworks or logos as a way of making some much-needed income.
content: LONDON — On Monday lunchtime, a steady trickle of people wandered into the gift shop of the National Gallery in the British capital, browsing souvenirs to mark their first visit to a museum since Britain started emerging from lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Miller
title: How the Creators of ‘Cursed’ Conjured a Fresh Take on King Arthur
description: Frank Miller and Tom Wheeler shared a love for the medieval legend but knew it had been done many times before. So they put a teen sorceress at the center.
content: Merlin, King Arthur, the Lady of the Lake. Yeah, we all know the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: Washington State Beat Back Covid-19. Now It’s Rising Again.
description: Washington was the initial epicenter of the nation’s coronavirus outbreak, and an early lockdown helped contain it. Six months later, cases are spiking again, and the future looks uncertain.
content: YAKIMA, Wash. — In what seems like almost a lifetime ago, America’s coronavirus story started in January in Washington State, with the nation’s first confirmed case followed by an early outbreak that spread with alarming ferocity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Hughes
title: Don’t Defund the Police. Re-Fund Them, Smarter.
description: I am a Black police officer. We need to change what it means to serve our communities.
content: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. — When I entered the police force in Virginia in 1987, I was one of the few Black officers in my department. On my first day on patrol, I was paired with an experienced white officer. As we prepared to hit the streets, he went over what he expected from me as a rookie. Then he pulled away from the curb and added, offhandedly: “Oh, if I call someone a nigger tonight, don’t get upset. It’s not directed at you, it’s directed at them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: Bill Stepien Takes Helm of Trump Campaign as a Data-Obsessed Political Fighter
description: Mr. Stepien, a former aide to Chris Christie who has been shadowed by the Bridgegate scandal, brings a data-centric style to the president’s lagging re-election effort.
content: It was a sudden announcement made late Wednesday, one that signaled a sharp change of direction for the Trump campaign: Bill Stepien, a longtime political operative and deputy campaign manager for President Trump, would succeed Brad Parscale as campaign manager, as the president’s re-election effort struggles to gain its footing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Mortgage Rates Drop Below 3% for First Time, Tempting Home Buyers
description: Thanks to Federal Reserve policy, the average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 2.98 percent. That could spur buying and construction.
content: Home loans have never been cheaper, if you can find a willing lender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: U.K. Police Step Back on Victims’ Data, a Flash Point in Rape Cases
description: Forms asking for consent to comb devices such as phones and laptops had caused concerns that they would deter people from reporting crimes, particularly in rape and other sex cases.
content: LONDON — The police in England and Wales said on Thursday that they would stop routinely asking victims of crime to allow checks of their electronic devices, such as computers and laptops, after critics said the practice discouraged people from reporting offenses, particularly in sex cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Fatal Affair’ Review: Close Stalker
description: Nia Long and Omar Epps ignite a dangerous obsession in this hackneyed romantic melodrama.
content: There is so much recycled material in “Fatal Affair” that its carbon footprint must have been zero. That’s the good news in this Netflix dance of déjà vu, one with scarcely a camera move, plot swerve or line of dialogue that hasn’t already graced myriad romantic thrillers and special-victim police procedurals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Megan Twohey
title: How a Struggling Company Won $1.6 Billion to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Novavax just received the Trump administration’s largest vaccine contract. In the Maryland company’s 33-year history, it has never brought a vaccine to market.
content: In late February, as the coronavirus spread around the world, Dr. Richard Hatchett, the head of an international nonprofit that gives money to vaccine developers, got on an important call to discuss vaccine candidates after his plane touched down at London’s Heathrow Airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: E.U. Court Strikes Down Trans-Atlantic Data Transfer Pact
description: The ruling is the latest twist in a campaign by privacy-rights activists in Europe to prevent personal information from being transferred to countries with looser protections.
content: LONDON — Europe’s top court on Thursday struck down a trans-Atlantic agreement that allows scores of companies to move data between the European Union and the United States, causing uncertainty for businesses that rely on moving digital information seamlessly around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Witchcraft
description: Evan Kalish is hiding from us.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — “By the pricking of my thumbs, / Something wicked this way comes.” So says the second witch in Act IV, Scene 1 of that Scottish play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The ‘Black Lives Matter’ Street Art That Contain Multitudes
description: The works in Harlem and Lower Manhattan are much more than a challenge to President Trump; they are opportunities for Black artists and community togetherness.
content: The first word, Black, was designed by Tijay Mohammed, a Ghanaian-born artist, and used vibrant Kente fabric design and Adinkra symbols, which represent concepts like royalty, unity and legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What’s Behind the Shootings?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Gun violence has been rising lately in some of the biggest American cities. It’s happened in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and, perhaps most notably, Minneapolis, the scene of the brutal killing of George Floyd and the intense protests that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: He’s back at work, but wondering for how long.
description: Martin Navarro is back at work — but he’s not sure for how long. A respiratory therapist and sleep technician in Wasco, Calif., near Bakersfield, he works in a sleep lab that reopened this month after closing in March.
content: Martin Navarro is back at work — but he’s not sure for how long. A respiratory therapist and sleep technician in Wasco, Calif., near Bakersfield, he works in a sleep lab that reopened this month after closing in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: Kicked Out of China, and Other Real-Life Costs of a Geopolitical Meltdown
description: When countries clash, here’s what happens to those of us caught in the middle.
content: LONDON — Soon after I was informed in mid-March that my journalist visa for China had been canceled, I faced a dilemma: what to do with my collection of wooden staffs used in a style of Chinese martial arts that I had been practicing for nearly 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 16, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 16, 2020.
content: An article on Monday about oil and gas companies that are heading toward bankruptcy misidentified the scientific agency where Claus Zehner works. It is the European Space Agency, not the SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Thinks the Trumps Are Full of Beans
description: Ivanka Trump posed with a can of Goya beans after the company’s president praised her father. “Sadly, after Ivanka tweeted in Spanish, Trump immediately had her deported,” said Jimmy Fallon.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari, Michael Corkery and Nelson D. Schwartz
title: Consumers Came Back in June, but for How Long?
description: Retail sales increased 7.5 percent, but there are ominous signs that the rebound may fizzle as coronavirus cases rise through much of the country.
content: The American consumer came back last month, with retail sales increasing 7.5 percent from May as stores reopened in warm weather, shoppers shook off lockdown fatigue and the federal government pumped trillions of dollars of stimulus into the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: It’s Merkel’s Last Rodeo. Will a Pandemic Rescue Deal Seal Her Legacy?
description: Angela Merkel has been the German chancellor for 15 years. Forging European consensus on a bitterly disputed recovery fund could burnish an uneven record.
content: BRUSSELS — Finishing her 15th year as chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel, the European Union’s longest-serving and most respected leader, now has her last, best chance to shape the future of the bloc and her own legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: The pandemic has bolstered to start-ups that provide end-of-life services.
description: Before the pandemic, end-of-life start-ups — companies that help clients plan funerals, dispose of remains and process grief — had experienced steady to moderate growth. Their founders were mostly women who hoped a mix of technology, customization and fresh thinking could take on the fusty and predominantly male funeral and estate-planning industries.
content: Before the pandemic, end-of-life start-ups — companies that help clients plan funerals, dispose of remains and process grief — had experienced steady to moderate growth. title: As Election Nears, Trump’s White House Grows Bolder in Flouting Ethical Norms
description: The outcry over a photograph of Ivanka Trump with a can of Goya beans reveals how the president and his aides continue to disregard traditional boundaries between the official and the political.
content: When President Trump holds official taxpayer-funded events outside Washington, his audiences are treated to campaign-style speeches and rock music playlists drawn from his political rallies. His appearances at the White House, most recently a rambling Rose Garden news conference, are increasingly devoid of policy and filled with attacks on the “radical left” and the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Mariana Simões
title: In Coronavirus Vaccine Race, China Strays From the Official Paths
description: Beijing is offering several vaccine candidates to employees of state-owned companies and the armed forces, while also conducting clinical trials in other countries.
content: The offer to employees at the state-owned oil giant was compelling: Be among the first in China to take a coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: The new “My Cat From Hell” special may resonate in unexpected ways. The new Hannibal Buress stand-up special almost certainly will.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

description: Hackers took control of prominent users’ accounts and asked for Bitcoin. Security researchers worry about serious flaws at the social network.

title: A Team by Any Other Name Is Fine, It Turns Out
description: The Washington N.F.L. franchise is picking a new name. As other pro franchises have learned, the process of rebranding can be as unique as the result.
content: When team owner Abe Pollin decided to change the name of the N.B.A.’s Washington Bullets in 1995, the two-year rebranding process had the veneer of a democratic undertaking.

author: By Molly Hensley-Clancy
title: Parenting in the Bubble: ‘This Is Mom’s Job. You Have to Work With Me.’
description: As sports return, some female athletes have entered restricted environments with their children in tow. Their leagues have taken steps to make it easier.
content: When her soccer team returned to the field in June, Amy Rodriguez had a familiar problem. Alone in Utah with her two sons, she needed to get back to work but had no way to hire child care help because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher, Elaine Yu and Russell Goldman
title: China’s economic rebound from the virus may be hard to sustain.
description: China’s economy expanded 3.2 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period last year, officials said on Thursday. The recovery is a sign, with caveats, of the authoritarian government’s success in bringing the outbreak under control with widespread testing and travel restrictions.
content: China’s economy expanded 3.2 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period last year, officials said on Thursday. author: By Dera Menra Sijabat and Richard C. Paddock
title: Police Officers Found Guilty in Acid Attack. But Doubts Remain.
description: The target of the 2017 attack, a corruption investigator in Indonesia who lost most of his sight, and supporters say officials have shown little interest in finding who was really behind it.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An anticorruption investigator, Novel Baswedan, was walking home from his neighborhood mosque in Jakarta three years ago when two men approached by motorbike and threw acid in his face. The attack left him blind in one eye and half-blind in the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Bourdeaux, Beth Cameron and Jonathan Zittrain
title: Testing Is on the Brink of Paralysis. That’s Very Bad News.
description: Our pandemic fight requires prompt testing results — and singular cooperation among the states to achieve them.
content: As Covid-19 cases surge to their highest levels in dozens of states, the nation’s testing effort is on the brink of paralysis because of widespread delays in getting back results. And that is very bad news, because even if testing is robust, the pandemic cannot be controlled without rapid results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Fauci Calls White House Criticism ‘Bizarre’
description: An under-fire public health expert gently hits back: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Fauci fights back while staying above the fray, and Trump strikes a blow at the “Magna Carta” of environmental law. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

description: The senator from Illinois joins the podcast to talk about Tucker Carlson, the vice presidency and parenting in a pandemic.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: U.K. women, Philippines, Siberia fires: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Black and other ethnic minority women in Britain are being disproportionately affected by the financial and psychological toll from the coronavirus outbreak, even as the economy reopens.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Have you read my colleague Elisabeth Egan’s column Group Text yet? You should: Once a month she picks a book that lends itself to discussion and offers up a kind of review-slash-reading guide to help you navigate it. (That way you can feel like you’re in a book club even in lockdown, when your regular in-person book club might feel deadlier than normal.) This month Liz picked Michele Harper’s memoir “The Beauty in Breaking,” about the author’s life as an emergency room doctor, which is one of 10 new books we recommend this week: “Usually I read to escape,” Liz writes, explaining her choice. “This summer, I’m reading to learn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: British Vogue Editor Says the Magazine’s Security ‘Racially Profiled’ Him
description: Edward Enninful, who is Black, said in an Instagram post that he was told by a guard this week to “use the loading bay” as he arrived at work.
content: The editor of British Vogue, Edward Enninful, said he was racially profiled after being told by a security guard to “use the loading bay” as he entered the magazine’s offices in London this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler
title: CVS Fined for Prescription Errors and Poor Staffing at Pharmacies
description: Regulators faulted four locations in Oklahoma, a rare action that followed complaints at drugstore chains across the country.
content: In a rare public rebuke of the nation’s largest retail pharmacy chain, state regulators in Oklahoma cited and fined CVS for conditions found at four of its pharmacies, including inadequate staffing and errors made in filling prescriptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: The Many Dimensions of the Chief Justice’s Triumphant Term
description: Among them: Religion got a place at the public table long reserved for secular society.
content: For once, the conventional wisdom was right: The Supreme Court term that ended last week was a triumph for Chief Justice John Roberts. But, as usual, the conventional wisdom skims the surface, focusing on the obvious: his steering of the court toward a center comfortably aligned with public opinion, and protecting it from an institutionally destructive alliance with a president who assumed the court would do his bidding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Must We Make Your Stepfather’s Coronavirus Sickness a Political Issue?
description: My liberal-leaning son doesn’t think I’ve been taking the pandemic seriously. Now my husband is sick, and my son says it’s our fault.
content: My 24-year-old son and I bicker constantly over politics. He thinks I’m hypnotized by Fox News. I’m not, but I’m not impressed by his knee-jerk liberal positions either. I never doubted our love for each other. But when Covid-19 came, he began accusing his stepfather and me of not taking the virus seriously. (We’ve always followed our state’s mandates.) Now, my husband has become seriously ill with the virus. And my son has been nasty about it: blaming us and saying, “I told you so,” rather than helping me or being sympathetic. I am devastated. What can I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Big Banks’ ‘Revolutionary’ Request: Please Don’t Weaken This Rule
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is on the verge of defanging an antidiscrimination rule. Four big banks are asking it not to.
content: Banks rarely object when the government wants to ease the rules. But current events have them asking regulators to at least tap the brakes on weakening a regulation meant to curb racial injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
title: As stores reopen, retailers say customer behavior is hit and miss.
description: The psyche of the American shopper is volatile. Just ask Andrew Moquin, who reopened his jewelry store early last month, after three months of lockdown.
content: The psyche of the American shopper is volatile. Just ask Andrew Moquin, who reopened his jewelry store early last month, after three months of lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: North Carolina City Approves Reparations for Black Residents
description: The measure passed by the City Council of Asheville, N.C., would provide funding to promote homeownership and business opportunities, but stopped short of stipulating direct payments.
content: As Americans debate how far the country should go to make amends for slavery and other racial injustices, a conversation reawakened by the killing of George Floyd, a city in North Carolina has taken the first step: It approved reparations for Black residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Putin’s People’ Documents the Ruthless and Relentless Reach of Kremlin Corruption
description: Catherine Belton’s new book argues that Vladimir Putin has presided over the country and its resources like a czar, bolstered by a cadre of friendly oligarchs and secret service agents.
content: In the years that it took the journalist Catherine Belton to research and write “Putin’s People,” her voluminous yet elegant account of money and power in the Kremlin, a number of her interview subjects tried various tactics to undermine her work. One of them, “a close Putin ally” apparently alarmed by her questions about Russian President Vladimir Putin’s activities as a K.G.B. agent in Dresden in the 1980s, emphatically insisted that any rumored links between the K.G.B. and terrorist organizations had never been proved: “And you should not try to do so!” he warned.

content: Every so often, a movie comes along that isn’t particularly good, yet somehow gets to you — even as your eyes start to roll, they can’t look away. “Dirt Music” is one of those, a strangely fascinating delivery system for so much visual beauty that its flaws scrabble to gain a purchase. content: AT THE OUTSET of “The Decameron,” the 14th-century story collection by the Italian writer Giovanni Boccaccio, a group of 10 young nobles — seven women and three men — flee “the death-dealing pestilence” sweeping through Florence and make their way to a country repast in the Tuscan hills. “Using very temperately of the most delicate viands and the finest wines and eschewing all incontinence,” Boccaccio writes, as translated by John Payne, of their carefree, 10-day idyll, “they abode with music and such other diversions as they might have, never suffering themselves to speak with any nor choosing to hear any news from without of death or sick folk.” They dined off “tables laid with the whitest of cloths and beakers that seemed of silver,” sustaining themselves according to the common medical wisdom of the day, which held that a cheerful disposition was as necessary to keep the plague at bay as the right kind of food.

content: BRAVE NEW WORLD Stream on Peacock. Aldous Huxley’s 1932 dystopian novel, “Brave New World,” has been ripped from the hands of your high school English teacher and thrown onscreen with this new TV adaptation. One of the highest-profile titles from NBCUniversal’s new streaming service, Peacock, the show brings to life the futuristic New London, a city where crime and disease are in the past, and residents spend their time popping happy pills and having orgies. At the story’s center are Bernard (Harry Lloyd) and Lenina (Jessica Brown Findlay), two New Londoners who bring a pair of outsiders, played by Alden Ehrenreich and Demi Moore, into the city. While the creators of the series make an effort to cook up a version of Huxley’s vision that feels fresh to 21st-century audiences, James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times that the show ultimately “transmutes a provocative warning into a vision of a sci-fi world that feels neither brave nor new.”

His lush language invites us into the exquisite realms here at our feet — or beyond that tree, there, in the cracks between the old stones. title: The Designer Who Defined Modern Parisian Cool
description: Isabel Marant has always known exactly how she wants to dress. In the decades since she founded her brand, people all over the world have adopted her tastes as their own.
content: “I was a strange and rebellious child,” says the designer Isabel Marant, who, after her French father and German mother separated when she was 7, was largely raised — in the Parisian suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine — by her stepmother, who was from Martinique and dressed in head-to-toe Yves Saint Laurent. The glamour wasn’t wasted on Marant, but she had her own ideas. “That era of ’80s super-chic French fashion was really getting on my nerves,” she says. “By 10, I knew exactly what I wanted to wear, but it didn’t exist in any shop.” So she started making her own clothes, reworking her dad’s castoff dressing gowns, sweaters, vintage military fatigues and silk slippers. At one point she thought she might study economics or become a veterinarian, but her friends loved her creations and kept requesting versions for themselves. After studying fashion design at Paris’s Studio Berçot, Marant launched Twen, a knitwear and jersey line, with her mother in 1989. “I was determined to work for myself,” she says. Her eponymous label debuted five years later, with a collection of men’s-wear-inspired overcoats and striped suits that drew from Indonesian batiks and ikats. Her credo was simple: She’d only design pieces she herself would wear. “To this day,” says Marant, 53, “nothing leaves the workshop without me trying it on.”
